docs.abstract: What should be more important to women: A positive body image or a fit physique that is less at risk for diabetes and other health issues?
docs.snippet: What should be more important to women: A positive body image or a fit physique that is less at risk for diabetes and other health issues?

headline.main: More Omega-3s in Diet, Less of an Alzheimer's Protein
headline.print_headline: Vital Signs: Nutrition: More Omega-3, Less of a Suspect Protein

docs.abstract: A study shows consumption of omega-3 fatty acids is associated with lower blood levels of beta-amyloid protein, a possible indication of increased risk for Alzheimer's disease.
docs.snippet: A study shows consumption of omega-3 fatty acids is associated with lower blood levels of beta-amyloid protein, a possible indication of increased risk for Alzheimer's disease.

headline.main: Post Your Questions on Healthy (and Tasty) Eating

docs.abstract: The journalist and author of "Culinary Intelligence: The Art of Eating Healthy (And Really Well)" will answer reader questions on how to relish the act of eating without sending your body into a tailspin.
docs.snippet: The journalist and author of "Culinary Intelligence: The Art of Eating Healthy (And Really Well)" will answer reader questions on how to relish the act of eating without sending your body into a tailspin.

headline.main: Congress Returns to Full Agenda Awash in Election Year Politics

docs.abstract: As Congress returns Monday after a week's recess, various pieces of legislation move to the front burner of partisan discord.
docs.snippet: As Congress returns Monday after a week's recess, various pieces of legislation move to the front burner of partisan discord.

docs.lead_paragraph: LEVENSON--Stanley M., M.D., 95, University Professor Emeritus, Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Bronx, NY, died on March 28, 2012, in San Francisco, CA. He was born in Boston, MA, on May 25, 1916, the son of Anna and Nathan and brother of Irving. He attended Boston Latin School '33; Harvard College '37; and Harvard Medical School '41. After medical school, he worked on development of the oxygen mask used during World War II. As an intern at Beth Israel Hospital in Boston, he met Eleanor Belloff, a nurse, who became his wife of more than 51 years. He began work at Boston City Hospital as a burn fellow shortly before the Cocoanut Grove fire, a major event in the history of burn care. Beginning in 1947, he served as Chief, Radiobiology, Army Medical Nutrition Laboratory in Chicago. At the Medical College of Virginia in Richmond, he was a resident in surgery. In 1953, he moved to Walter Reed Army Institute of Research, Washington, D.C., where he was Chief, Surgical Metabolism; Director, Basic Surgical Research; and Director, Germfree Research. He was also Associate Clinical Professor of Surgery, Georgetown Medical School. In 1961, he joined the faculty of Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Bronx, NY, as Professor of Surgery; Director, Surgical Intensive Care - Burn Unit; and Director, Germfree Research Program. He became University Professor in 1986 and University Professor Emeritus in 1987. He worked until 2002, when he moved to San Francisco, CA. He was the author or co-author of more than 390 publications on burns, nutrition, wound healing, and other subjects. He received many honors including: National Institutes of Health Research Career Award, 1962-1987; Harvey S. Allen Distinguished Service Award, American Burn Association, 1976; McCollum Award, American Society for Clinical Nutrition, 1983; first Lifetime Achievement Award, Wound Healing Society, 1993; first Lifetime Achievement Award, Jacobi Hospital, Bronx Municipal Hospital Medical Center, 1999. He was predeceased by his parents, brother, and wife. He is survived by his daughters: Toby Sherwood of San Francisco, CA, and Laurie (Gary) Mesibov of Chapel Hill, NC; two grandsons: Brian (Sally) Mesibov of Charlotte, NC, and Todd Mesibov (Kate Eyes) of Chapel Hill, NC, and three great-granddaughters: Anna, Claire, and Eleanor. A Funeral was held April 1, 2012, and he was buried next to his wife in Greenwich, CT. The family may be reached at: smlevensonfamily @gmail.com.

docs.lead_paragraph: How many middle-aged white women fear their husbands will find them less attractive if their weight drops to less than 200 pounds?
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by author Alice Randall observes that the problem of obesity in black women is in part due to a notion that a larger, curvier body is more desirable; calls for a body-culture revolution in black America in order to combat diabetes.
docs.snippet: How many middle-aged white women fear their husbands will find them less attractive if their weight drops to less than 200 pounds?

docs.lead_paragraph: With new food, revamped décor and an embrace of mommy blogs, McDonald’s isn’t just trying to keep its customers. It’s trying to convince skeptics that they’re wrong.

headline.main: How McDonald’s Came Back Bigger Than Ever

docs.abstract: Keith O'Brien article examines McDonald's launch of a major rebranding effort with new food and revamped decor; notes effort is attempt to come back from series of public relations debacles in an increasingly health-conscious time.
docs.snippet: With new food, revamped décor and an embrace of mommy blogs, McDonald’s isn’t just trying to keep its customers. It’s trying to convince skeptics that they’re wrong.
